poem:
### Unsung Cipher

In the quiet cipher's hum,  
beyond Turing's celebrated shade,  
she sits, a quiet storm of thought,  
in grey wool, tea lukewarm.   

The click and clatter of keys,  
a symphony against the tide,  
hands nimble, unravel threads,  
as the Atlantic slumbers safer.  

Unseen hero, encoded heart  
within Bletchley's whispered halls.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Move over, Alan Turing: meet the working-class hero of Bletchley Park you didn’t see in the movies This is a story you know, right? It’s early in the war and western Europe has fallen. Only the Channel stands between Britain and the fascist yoke; only Atlantic shipping lanes offer hope of the population continuing to be fed, clothed and armed. But hunting “wolf packs” of Nazi U-boats pick off merchant shipping at will, coordinated by". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
